translated: Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, fascicle 100ğŸ”½
Abhidharma-mahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä-Å›Ästra, fascicle 186
Composed by 500 great arhats and othersğŸ”½Tripiá¹­aka master Xuanzang respectfully received
Question: Why was this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to analyze the meaning of the sÅ«tras.
As the sÅ«tras say:
Among sentient beings, some are fixed, some are unfixed.
Some have the bright path of sharp wisdom,
Some do not have the bright path of dull wisdom.
Although this is said, the distinctions in inclusion are not analyzed.
That sÅ«tra is the fundamental basis of this treatise.
What is not explained there should all be explained now.
Therefore, this treatise is composed.
Question: Are all those who are unfixed not of the dull wisdom and dark path?
Answer: All those who are unfixed are not of the dull wisdom and dark path.
There are those who are of the dull wisdom and dark path but are not unfixed.
Namely, those of wrong fixation.
Question: Are all those who are fixed of the sharp wisdom and bright path?
Answer: Those who are wise, bright, and of right practice are all definitely so.
There are those who are definitely so, but are not wise or of right practice.
This refers to those of wrong practice.
Here, those who are not wise are ordinary beings, because they lack the wisdom of the noble ones.
Those who are wise are the noble ones, because they possess the wisdom of the noble ones.
How do we know this?
Because it is said in the sutras.
As a sutra says:
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
What do you think?
Those who know the noble truth of suffering as it really is,
the noble truth of the arising of suffering, the noble truth of the cessation of suffering,
and the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering as it really is,
or those who do not know this as it really is,
who among them are called the wise ones here?
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
According to the meaning of what the Buddha has said,
those who know the noble truth of suffering,
up to the noble truth of the path leading to the cessation of suffering as it really is are called the wise ones,
not those who do not know this as it really is.
Therefore, we know that the noble ones are wise and the ordinary beings are not wise.
The wise ones are the basis for proceeding towards light and illumination.
The unwise ones are the basis for proceeding towards ignorance and darkness.
All those who are undetermined are all unwise.
Those who proceed towards ignorance refer to those who are undetermined, who must be ordinary beings.
All ordinary beings are all unwise.
They are included in proceeding towards ignorance.
There are those who are unwise and proceed towards ignorance but are not undetermined.
Those who are wrongly determined are also necessarily ordinary beings.
They are not called undetermined because they are determined in wrong natures.
All those who are wise and proceed towards light are necessarily determined.
The noble ones are called determined because they are determined in right natures.
Are all those who are undetermined not those who do not accomplish the factors of enlightenment?
Answer: All those who are undetermined are all those who do not accomplish the factors of enlightenment.
There are those who do not accomplish the factors of enlightenment but are not undetermined.
It means that those of wrong determination are ordinary beings, and their nature is determined as wrong.
Do all those who attain the factors of enlightenment definitely attain them?
The answer is: Those who attain the factors of enlightenment definitely attain them.
There are those who attain them but do not attain the factors of enlightenment.
It means those of wrong determination, as explained above.
There are three groups:
The group of those determined as of wrong nature,
The group of those determined as of right nature,
And the indeterminate group. The group of those determined as of wrong nature
Refers to those who have committed the five heinous crimes.
The group of those determined as of right nature refers to those who have attained the dharmas of learners and adepts.
The indeterminate group refers to those who have only attained the remaining contaminated dharmas and the unconditioned.
This is called the intrinsic nature of the three groups.
In terms of realms, the group of those determined as of wrong nature belongs to one realm,
Namely the desire realm.
The group of those determined as of right nature belongs to three realms.
The indeterminate group is also like this.
In terms of destinies, the group of those determined as of wrong nature belongs to one destiny,
Namely the human realm.
The group of those determined as of right nature belongs to two destinies,
Namely the human and heavenly realms.
The indeterminate aggregate includes the three destinies in their entirety.
Namely, the hells, animals, and hungry ghosts.
And a part of two destinies.
Namely, humans and gods.
Those of wrong nature and fixed aggregate include one birth in part.
Namely, womb birth.
Those of right nature and fixed aggregate include two births in part.
Namely, womb birth and transformation birth.
The indeterminate aggregate includes two births in their entirety.
Namely, egg birth and moisture birth.
And two births in part.
Namely, the other two births.
Some say:
Those of wrong nature and fixed aggregate include three births in part.
Excluding transformation birth.
Those of right nature and fixed aggregate and the indeterminate aggregate also include four births in part.
As for realms, some say:
Those of wrong nature and fixed aggregate include three realms in part.
Those of right nature and fixed aggregate include five realms in their entirety.
And twenty-four realms in part.
The indeterminate aggregate includes five realms in their entirety.
And twenty-four realms in part.
According to this explanation,ğŸ”½all conditioned phenomena have forty realms.
The indeterminate aggregate includes eleven realms in their entirety.
and a small part of the twenty-four places.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
From AvÄ«ci hell up to the peak of existence, there are three groups.
They say that the dharmas that are destined for parinirvÄá¹‡a are called the group of right nature,
the dharmas that are not destined for parinirvÄá¹‡a are called the group of wrong nature,
and the undetermined ones are called the group of undetermined nature.
The evaluators say:
The previous explanation is better.
This is based on the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya.
If based on the PrajÃ±aptiÅ›Ästra,
the group of wrong nature refers to the five immediate karmas,
if they are the causes, fruits, natural outflow, or retribution of that, and the pudgala who accomplishes those dharmas.
The group of right nature refers to the dharmas of learners and non-learners,
if they are the causes, fruits, or natural outflow of that,
and the pudgala who accomplishes those dharmas.
The undetermined group refers to the remaining dharmas,
if they are the causes, fruits,
natural outflow, or retribution of that,
and the pudgala who accomplishes those dharmas.
This is called the intrinsic nature of the three groups.
The realms are as explained above.
The destinies are the two destinies of the group of those with wrong nature and the group of those with right nature.
This refers to the hells and humans.
The group of those with right nature also refers to the two destinies of humans and gods.
The group of those with indeterminate nature refers to the two complete destinies of animals and hungry ghosts.
It also refers to the three destinies of the hells, humans, and gods.
As for birth, the group of those with wrong nature refers to the two types of birth of those with wrong nature.
This refers to birth from the womb and birth from transformation.
The group of those with right nature refers to the four types of birth.
The group of those with indeterminate nature is also like this.
The distinctions of locations should be understood as appropriate.
The Vinaya says:
The World-Honored One, under the Bodhi tree, established all sentient beings into three groups.
This is called the group of those with wrong nature.
This is called the group of those with right nature.
This is called the group of those with indeterminate nature.
Question: Are they established based on the limits of sentient beings?
Or are they based on the limits of the Dharma?
If it is based on sentient beings,
How is it not the limit of the ocean of sentient beings that can be attained?
If it is based on the Dharma,
the Å›rÄvakas are also able to establish it in this way.
What is not shared by the Buddha and the Å›rÄvakas?
Some say:
It is based on sentient beings to establish it.
Question: If so,
how is it not the limit of the ocean of sentient beings that can be attained?
Answer: The Buddha attaining the limit of the ocean of sentient beings is also without fault.
However, it is attained in general characteristics, not in specific characteristics.
That is to say, all sentient beings do not go beyond the four modes of birth.
It is attained in this way.
Some say:
It is based on the Dharma to establish it.
Question: If so,
the Å›rÄvakas are also able to establish it in this way.
What is not shared by the Buddha and the Å›rÄvakas?
Answer: The Å›rÄvakas hear it from the Buddha.
The Buddha is able to establish it on his own without a teacher.
This is what is not shared.
Some say:
If it is based on sentient beings to establish it, it is the three thousand worlds and the thousand years that have passed.
If in other worlds and at other times, the establishment of dharmas is based on other [methods].
Question: If the Buddha has already established sentient beings into three groups under the Bodhi tree,
why does he say again that he observes the world with the Buddha eye six times a day and night?
Answer: Although he has previously established the three groups,
he has not yet observed the distinctions in their states.
Who at what time enters the indeterminate group from the group of wrong determination?
Who at what time enters the group of right determination or the group of wrong determination from the indeterminate group?
In order to know this, he observes again with the Buddha eye day and night.
Some say:
In order to show that the Buddha always delights in contemplating benefiting others at all times.
Some say:
In order to show that the World-Honored One's mind is pervaded by great compassion without indolence.
Venerable Vasumitra says:
There are sentient beings who repeatedly come to be born in this land from other worlds.
Because they have not been established before,
now he observes them with the Buddha eye and re-establishes them.
Venerable BodhyÄá¹£á¹­i says:
The Buddha takes the Dharma as his teacher.
In order to respectfully serve the Dharma,
he observes the world with the Buddha eye six times during the day and night.
Venerable Subhagupta says:
The Buddha wants to show that what he does is well-considered,
so although he has established [the teachings], he still observes [them].
For those who have accomplished the factors of enlightenment,
do they also accomplish the uncontaminated dharmas?
Answer: Those who have accomplished the factors of enlightenment have also accomplished the uncontaminated dharmas.
Because the factors of enlightenment are uncontaminated.
There are those who have accomplished the uncontaminated dharmas but not the factors of enlightenment.
This refers to ordinary beings.
Because all ordinary beings have accomplished non-analytical cessation.
Because they also have accomplished analytical cessation according to the level of defilements they have abandoned.
For those who have not accomplished the factors of enlightenment,
do they also not accomplish the uncontaminated dharmas?
Answer: There are none who do not accomplish the uncontaminated dharmas.
Because they necessarily have accomplished non-analytical cessation.
There are those who have not accomplished the factors of enlightenment.
It refers to ordinary beings.
Because ordinary beings necessarily do not possess conditioned and uncontaminated dharmas.
Do those who obtain the factors of enlightenment also obtain uncontaminated dharmas?
The answer is: Those who obtain the factors of enlightenment also obtain uncontaminated dharmas.
There are those who obtain uncontaminated dharmas but not the factors of enlightenment.
It refers to ordinary beings.
The question is: The words obtaining the factors of enlightenment
are reasonable.
Because when entering the stage of certainty of liberation, one obtains what was not previously obtained.
How can it be said that one obtains uncontaminated dharmas?
Because there is no originally unestablished non-analytical cessation.
Some say:
This text should only say obtaining the factors of enlightenment.
It should not say obtaining uncontaminated dharmas.
Some say:
Here, uncontaminated dharmas are of two kinds.
One is the factors of enlightenment, the other is analytical cessation.
When entering the stage of certainty of liberation, one obtains the factors of enlightenment.
When one is free from any category of defilement, one obtains analytical cessation.
Ordinary beings, in the eight stages, attain the cessation of discrimination with regard to the objects abandoned by the path of insight and the path of cultivation.
Therefore, this statement is made.
Some say:
Here, there are three kinds of pure dharmas.
First, the factors of enlightenment; second, cessation through discrimination; third, cessation not through discrimination.
When one enters the stage of right and definite progress, one attains the factors of enlightenment.
When one is free from any category of defilement, one attains cessation through discrimination.
At any time, one attains cessation not through discrimination.
Question: Aren't ordinary beings originally all endowed with cessation not through discrimination?
Why is it said that they attain it?
Answer: Although they are originally endowed with it, it can also be said that they attain it in the stage of superior progress.
For example, by means of giving,
by means of precepts,
by means of hearing,
by means of contemplation,
by means of the contemplation of impurity, mindfulness of breathing, or the foundations of mindfulness,
or by means of the stages of heat, summit, patience, and the highest worldly dharmas,
one causes the dharmas of the evil destinies, etc., to attain cessation not through discrimination.
Furthermore, if it is spoken of in terms of categories, it should not be said that one attains it.
If we speak in terms of the distinctions of events, we can also say that they are attained.
Because in each moment, according to each event, they are attained separately.
Do those who abandon the factors of enlightenment also abandon the uncontaminated dharmas?
The answer is: There is no complete abandonment of the factors of enlightenment.
Nor is there complete abandonment of the uncontaminated dharmas.
Because it is impossible for the noble ones to revert to being ordinary beings.
And because there are no sentient beings who do not accomplish non-analytical cessation.
However, there is no complete abandonment because there is the meaning of partial abandonment.
Do those who regress from the factors of enlightenment also regress from the uncontaminated dharmas?
The answer is: There is no complete regression from the factors of enlightenment.
Nor is there complete regression from the uncontaminated dharmas.
The meaning is explained as before.
Furthermore, in order to stop the MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika school's claim that the fruit of stream-entry can be regressed from,
and to stop the SautrÄntikas' denial of the existence of non-analytical cessation,
this is said.
There is no complete abandonment or complete regression from the factors of enlightenment or the uncontaminated dharmas.
Are those not yet abandoned not yet fully understood?
And so on, explaining in detail.
Here, the treatise is composed based on two kinds of complete knowledge.
First, complete knowledge of cognition.
Second, complete knowledge of elimination.
Within complete knowledge of cognition,
some say:
Only uncontaminated cognition.
Some say:
Both contaminated and uncontaminated cognition.
Those who say it is only uncontaminated cognition,
they say that at the time of realizing suffering, with regard to the five dharmas to be eliminated, one is called completely knowing by means of complete knowledge of cognition.
With regard to the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing suffering, one is called eliminating by means of complete knowledge of elimination.
At the time of realizing accumulation, it is also like this.
The difference is that one's own truth is spoken of.
At the time of realizing cessation, with regard to the truth of cessation, one is called completely knowing by means of complete knowledge of cognition.
With regard to the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing cessation, one is called eliminating by means of complete knowledge of elimination.
At the time of realizing the path, it is also like this.
The difference is that one's own truth is spoken of.
In the path of cultivation, no matter what cognition arises, with regard to any dharma that is the object,
one is called completely knowing by means of complete knowledge of cognition.
With regard to any dharma to be eliminated,
It is called eliminated because of the complete knowledge of elimination.
This is the brief explanation of this matter.
Are those not yet eliminated not yet completely known?
The answer is: Those not yet completely known are not yet eliminated.
Because one must know through wisdom in order to eliminate.
There are those that are not yet eliminated but not yet completely known.
This refers to those that are already completely known because they are completely known through wisdom,

but not already eliminated because they are not already eliminated through complete knowledge of elimination. This refers to those for whom the knowledge of suffering has arisen but the knowledge of accumulation has not yet arisen.
Regarding the four dharmas to be eliminated, they are already completely known because they are completely known through wisdom,
but not already eliminated because they are not already eliminated through complete knowledge of elimination.
For those for whom the knowledge of accumulation has arisen but the knowledge of cessation has not yet arisen,
regarding the three dharmas to be eliminated, for those for whom the knowledge of cessation has arisen but the knowledge of the path has not yet arisen,
regarding the two dharmas to be eliminated, for those for whom the knowledge of the path has arisen but who have not yet eliminated the defilements to be eliminated during cultivation,
regarding the one dharma to be eliminated, they are already completely known because they are completely known through wisdom,
but not already eliminated because they are not already eliminated through complete knowledge of elimination.
That is, for those who have already become free from the desire of the desire realm but have not yet become free from the desire of the higher realms,
In the form and formless realms, for dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation, having already abandoned attachment to form but not yet abandoned attachment above that,
in the formless realm, for dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation, they are already fully understood by means of the complete knowledge of cognition.
They are not already eliminated by means of the complete knowledge of elimination.
Are all those that have already been eliminated already fully understood?
The answer is: Those that have already been eliminated have already been fully understood.
This refers to when the cognition of suffering has already arisen but the cognition of accumulation has not yet arisen.
For one dharma to be eliminated, it is already fully understood by means of the complete knowledge of cognition.
It is already eliminated by means of the complete knowledge of elimination.
When the cognition of accumulation has already arisen but the cognition of cessation has not yet arisen,
for two dharmas to be eliminated, when the cognition of cessation has already arisen but the cognition of the path has not yet arisen,
for three dharmas to be eliminated, when the cognition of the path has already arisen but one has not yet abandoned the defilements to be eliminated by cultivation,
for four dharmas to be eliminated, they are already fully understood by means of the complete knowledge of cognition.
They are already eliminated by means of the complete knowledge of elimination.
That very [person], having already abandoned attachment to the desire realm but not yet abandoned attachment above that,
for the dharmas to be eliminated by seeing in the three realms
and the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm,
Having already separated from the defilements of the form realm but not yet separated from those above,
with regard to the three realms' objects to be eliminated by the path of seeing,
and the objects to be eliminated by the path of cultivation in the desire and form realms, the knowledge of elimination has already arisen.
With regard to the objects to be eliminated by the path of seeing and cultivation in the three realms, they are already fully understood due to the full understanding by knowledge.
They are already eliminated due to the full understanding by elimination.
There are those who have already fully understood but have not yet eliminated.
This refers to those who have already fully understood due to the full understanding by knowledge,
but have not yet eliminated due to the full understanding by elimination.
This refers to when the knowledge of suffering has already arisen but the knowledge of accumulation has not yet arisen.
With regard to the four objects to be eliminated, etc., it is explained in detail as above.
Those who say that the full understanding by knowledge includes both contaminated and uncontaminated knowledge,
they say that during the stage of the roots of goodness that accord with penetration,
with regard to the five objects to be eliminated, they are called fully understood due to the full understanding by knowledge.
They are not called eliminated due to the full understanding by elimination.
The stages of the path of seeing and the path of cultivation are explained as above.
Question: Aren't all phenomena already called fully understood during the stage of the applications of mindfulness?
Answer: Although it is also called complete knowledge, it is not the superior progress.
Here, the superior progress is explained.
If the aspect is the same as the noble path, it is called the superior progress.
Some say:
If it is wisdom accomplished through hearing, thinking, or cultivation,
if it is the heat, summit, patience, or supreme worldly dharmas,
because it completely knows the specific and general characteristics of contaminated things, it is all called the complete knowledge of wisdom.
This is the brief discussion here.
Are all those not yet eliminated not yet completely known?
Answer: Those not yet completely known are not yet eliminated.
Because one first attains the complete knowledge of wisdom regarding them, and then later eliminates them and attains complete knowledge.
There are those not yet eliminated but not yet completely known.
This refers to those that are already completely known because of the complete knowledge of wisdom,
but are not yet eliminated because of the complete knowledge of elimination.
This refers to the roots of goodness conducive to penetration that have already arisen, and the path of seeing that has not yet arisen.
Regarding the five dharmas to be eliminated, they are already completely known because of the complete knowledge of wisdom,
but are not yet eliminated because of the complete knowledge of elimination.
The rest is explained in detail as above.
Have all those who have already eliminated it already fully known it?
The answer is: Those who have already eliminated it have already fully known it.
This is explained as above.
There are those who have already fully known it but have not yet eliminated it.
This refers to those who have already fully known it through the knowledge of elimination.
But have not yet eliminated it through the knowledge of elimination.
This refers to those who have already given rise to the roots of goodness conducive to penetration, and so on.
The detailed explanation is as above.
Although ordinary beings have eliminated [afflictions], it is not the elimination through full knowledge.
Therefore, it is not mentioned.
Because it is not realized through the full knowledge of knowledge.
Because the full knowledge of knowledge is only characterized by the noble path.
Those who are born in this life but do not see forms with the eyes,
on what basis do they give rise to the divine eye?
And so on, in detail.
Question: Why did he compose this treatise?
Answer: In order to make the doubtful attain certainty.
As the Abhidharma states:ğŸ”½How does one practice the supernormal knowledge of death and rebirth?
How does one give rise to the supernormal knowledge of death and rebirth?
It means that a beginner, in the worldly samÄdhi,
has already well cultivated and attained mastery, causing it to manifest.
In order to induce the supernormal power of the divine eye,
first one grasps the appearance of a pure mirror surface,
or the appearance of the orbs of the sun, moon, stars, palaces, herbs, lamps, jewels, and various lights,
or the appearance of a great bonfire burning many yojanas of cities and towns, blazing with flames.
Having grasped these appearances, by the power of conceptual imagination,
in the state of not seeing, one is able to give rise to light,
and by the continuity of resolve, induce the divine eye.ğŸ”½Sometimes, right where the ordinary eyes are, there arises the pure divine eye of the form realm, which is derived from the great elements,
able to see various forms, whether good or bad,
and so on at length.
Or there may be those who give rise to such doubts:
Those whose eyes in this life do not see forms,
are they then unable to induce the divine eye?
In order to cause this doubt to be resolved,
It shows that although the eyes of this life do not see forms, they can still give rise to the divine eye.
Therefore, this treatise is composed.
Moreover, the PrajÃ±aptiÅ›Ästra says:ğŸ”½What is the practice of the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear?
How does one attain the supernormal knowledge of the divine ear?ğŸ”½It is said that a beginner,
having already well cultivated and well mastered the worldly samÄdhi, causes it to manifest.
In order to attain the divine ear, one first grasps the sounds of elephants, horses, and carriages,
or the sounds of bells, drums, gongs, conches, flutes, pipes, singing, chanting, and so forth,
or the sounds produced by the mutual striking of the four great elements.
Having well grasped these various sounds,
by the power of conceptual imagination, one is able to produce various sounds even when apart from hearing.
One continues to cultivate this understanding and attains the divine ear.
Sometimes, right at the place of the ordinary ear,
the pure divine ear composed of form-realm primary elements arises.
It is able to hear various sounds, whether human or non-human,
and so forth, in great detail.
Because of this, there arises such a doubt.
Those who have this life but whose ears do not hear sounds,
they should not be able to give rise to the divine ear.
In order to cause this doubt to be resolved,
it is shown that although in this life the ears do not hear sounds,
they are also able to give rise to the divine ear.
Therefore, this treatise is composed.
Those who have this life but whose eyes do not see forms,
on what basis do they give rise to the divine eye?
Answer: It is like someone who attains recollection born from their own nature.
In a previous life, the eyes once saw forms.
Based on this, they give rise to the divine eye.
Those who have this life but whose ears do not hear sounds,
on what basis do they give rise to the divine ear?
Answer: It is like someone who attains recollection born from their own nature.
In a previous life, the ears once heard sounds.
Based on this, they give rise to the divine ear.
Question: Those who attain the knowledge of recollecting past abodes and lives,
are also able to give rise to the divine eye and divine ear. Why is this not mentioned here?
The answer is that although it should be explained, it is not explained.
One should know that this meaning is incomplete.
Some say:
If the heavenly eye of the blind and the heavenly ear of the deaf can both be induced, it is explained here.
The knowledge of recollecting past abodes.
Only able to induce that kind of heavenly eye, not the heavenly ear.
Why is it so?
Because those who are born deaf do not have the knowledge of recollecting past abodes.
Because this knowledge arises only through the teachings of others.
Therefore, it is not explained.
Question: Why is the heavenly eye only in the four fundamental meditations and not in the preliminary stages?
Answer: It is not their field, not their vessel.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Furthermore, if a stage has the concentration that is the basis for spiritual powers, then it has the heavenly eye.
Because the preliminary stages do not have the concentration that is the basis for spiritual powers, they do not have the heavenly eye.
Furthermore, if a stage has the concentration that is included in the factors [of enlightenment], then it has the heavenly eye.
The preliminary stages are not like this.
Some say:
If there is a path of pleasant practice on a certain level, then there is the divine eye on that level.
The preliminary stages are not like this.
Thus, the divine eye is sometimes said to be only one kind,
namely the divine eye.
Sometimes it is said to be two kinds,
namely the previously acquired and the newly acquired.
Sometimes it is said to be three kinds,
namely weak, medium, and strong.
Sometimes it is said to be four kinds,
namely the fruits of the four meditations.
Sometimes it is said to be six kinds,
namely the weak, medium, and strong, each divided into previously acquired and newly acquired.
Sometimes it is said to be eight kinds,
namely the fruits of the four meditations, each divided into previously acquired and newly acquired.
Sometimes it is said to be nine kinds,
namely the weakest, up to the strongest.
Sometimes it is said to be twelve kinds,
namely the fruits of the four meditations, each divided into weak, medium, and strong.
Sometimes it is said to be eighteen kinds,
namely the weakest, up to the strongest, each divided into previously acquired and newly acquired.
Sometimes it is said to be twenty-four kinds,
namely the first six of each of the four meditations.
Sometimes it is said to be thirty-two kinds,
namely sixteen innate and sixteen cultivated.
Some say:
The fruits of the four meditations are each divided into soft, medium, and superior, making twelve.
Each is further divided into five grades of mixed cultivation of meditation, making twenty.
These are called the thirty-two.
Some say thirty-six:
The fruits of the four meditations are each divided into soft-soft up to superior-superior.
Some say seventy-two:
Each of the four meditations has the previous eighteen.
If divided by continuity and moment, there are innumerable [types].
Now, it is simply said that there is one divine eye.
The divine eye, divine ear, and so forth are also like this.
Question: Why do the divine eye and ear of different realms appear,
But the divine nose, tongue, and body of different realms do not appear?
Answer: The two faculties of eye and ear take distant objects.
In order to see and hear far away, the divine eye and ear of different realms appear.
The faculties of nose, tongue, and body only take proximate objects.
There is no separate function in different realms, so they do not appear.
Some say:
If the two different types of nose and tongue faculties appear,
it would be ridiculed by the world.
How could this person have two noses and two tongues?
If there are different types of body faculties appearing,
the world would also ridicule it.
How could this person be like a twin with two bodies?
Therefore, the nose and other faculties do not have different types.
Moreover, the heavenly eyes on the left and right are necessarily the same in excellence and inferiority.
That is to say, the left is not inferior and the right is not superior, and so on.
Moreover, when they appear, they are necessarily all complete.
There are no blind or missing ones, nor any blurred or confused ones, nor their different types.
The rest is explained in detail in the chapter on the aggregate of faculties and contact.
Question: Why do the bonds to be eliminated by insight and cultivation increase when ordinary beings retrogress?
When the disciples of the World-Honored One retrogress, only the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation increase?
Answer: Ordinary beings use this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by insight.
They use this same path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation.
Therefore, when they retrogress, both bonds increase.
The disciples of the World-Honored One use this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing.
They are definitely not retrogressing from this path.
Using other paths to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation,
they may or may not retrogress from the other paths.
Even if the disciples of the World-Honored One use this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing,
they also do not retrogress from using this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation.
Why is this treatise composed?
The answer is: to stop the intention of those who deny the existence of retrogressing nature.
To show that there is indeed retrogressing, this treatise is composed.
Here, the attainments are called increase and accumulation because they give rise to [the path].
Therefore, in some places, attainment is called near arising. Because it is near to the arising of that dharma.
As the Abhidharma Treatise says:
When the latent tendency of desire for sensual pleasure of ordinary beings arises, five dharmas arise.
First, the latent tendency of desire for sensual pleasure.
Second, the near arising of the latent tendency of desire for sensual pleasure.
Third, the latent tendency of ignorance.
Fourth, the near arising of the latent tendency of ignorance.
Fifth, agitation.
In this case, ordinary beings use this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing.
Those who use this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation,
They use the nine types of paths to simultaneously eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
When they regress, the two bonds are obtained simultaneously.
The disciples of the World-Honored One who use this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing,
They use the one type of path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing.
They are definitely not regressing from this path.
Those who use the remaining paths to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation,
They use the nine types of paths to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation.
They may regress from the remaining paths or not regress.
The disciples of the World-Honored One, even if they use this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing,
Those who use this path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation are also those who do not regress.
Even if they use the one type of path to simultaneously eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation, they do not regress.
Because the disciples of the World-Honored One definitely do not regress from the bonds to be eliminated by seeing.
Because it is impossible for them to abandon both simultaneously and then fall away from one.
Moreover, disciples of the Buddha, when they were ordinary beings, used the nine grades of the path to abandon the bonds that are to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
Now, they also do not fall away from the two paths that suppress [the bonds].
Furthermore, ordinary beings use the path of cultivation to simultaneously abandon the bonds that are to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
Therefore, when they fall away, the two bonds are obtained simultaneously.

They use the path of cultivation to eliminate the bonds that are to be eliminated by cultivation.
They may or may not fall away from this path.
The rest is explained according to the previous [principles].
Furthermore, ordinary beings use wisdom to simultaneously abandon the bonds that are to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
Therefore, when they fall away, the two bonds are obtained simultaneously.
The World-Honored One's disciples use patience to eliminate the bonds that are to be eliminated by seeing.
They are definitely not falling away from this path.
They use wisdom to eliminate the bonds that are to be eliminated by cultivation.

Moreover, ordinary beings do not simultaneously abandon the bonds to be abandoned by seeing and cultivation when contemplating the truths.
Therefore, when they retrogress, the two bonds are obtained simultaneously.
The disciples of the World-Honored One abandon the bonds to be abandoned by seeing when contemplating the truths.
They definitely do not retrogress from this path.

Moreover, ordinary beings simultaneously abandon the bonds to be abandoned by seeing and cultivation using the path that is both being produced and not being produced.
Therefore, when they retrogress, the two bonds are obtained simultaneously.
The disciples of the World-Honored One abandon the bonds to be abandoned by seeing using the path that is not being produced.
They definitely do not retrogress from this path.
They abandon the bonds to be abandoned by cultivation using the path that is both being produced and not being produced.
They may or may not retrogress from this path.
The rest is explained according to the previous pattern.
Moreover, ordinary beings simultaneously abandon the bonds to be abandoned by seeing and cultivation using a path that is not sharp.
Therefore, when they retrogress, the two bonds are obtained simultaneously.
The disciples of the World-Honored One use the sharp path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing.
They are definitely not retrogressing from this path.
Using the non-sharp path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation,
they may or may not retrogress from this path.ğŸ”½The rest is explained according to the previous.
Some say:
Ordinary beings use the contaminated path to simultaneously eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing and cultivation.
Therefore, when they retrogress, the two bonds arise together.
The disciples of the World-Honored One use the uncontaminated path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by seeing.
They are definitely not retrogressing from this path.
Using the contaminated and uncontaminated paths to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation,
they may or may not retrogress from this path.
However, they say that those who use the uncontaminated path to eliminate [bonds] are definitely not retrogressing.
Question: If that is so,
then there should be no retrogressing from the fruit of arhatship,
because the bonds of the peak of existence are eliminated only by the uncontaminated path.
Answer: If an arhat first uses the contaminated path to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation in the lower eight stages,
They may have retrogression.
Because the fundamental [roots] are not firm.
If one has previously used the uncontaminated path to sever the bonds to be severed by cultivation in the lower eight stages,
They will definitely not retrogress.
Because the fundamental [roots] are firm.
Why is there no one who retrogresses from the path of seeing?
The answer is: because the fundamental [roots] are firm.
What are the fundamental [roots]?
They refer to the giving, precepts, and cultivation of those who seek liberation, as well as the activities for the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹…gha,
Serving the old and sick, reading and reciting the holy teachings,
Expounding them for others, and proper contemplation.

Cultivating the contemplation of impurity, mindfulness of breathing, the three characteristics, the seven good factors, the heat stage, the peak stage, the forbearance stage, and the supreme mundane qualities.
All of these are called the fundamental roots of the path of seeing.
Some say:
The path of seeing is fierce and swift, able to sever the nine categories of bonds with a single category of path.
Therefore, there is no retrogression.
Some say:
The path of seeing is only a single moment, with the forbearance and knowledge present.
Therefore, there is no retrogression.
Some say:
If one can retrogress from the path of seeing, then the holy life one cultivates cannot be relied upon.
Because one can retrogress from the path of seeing and become an ordinary person again.
Question: As for the arhats who use other paths to eliminate the bonds to be eliminated through cultivation,
are there those who retrogress and those who do not retrogress in those other paths?
Who retrogresses and who does not?
Answer: The occasional liberation [arhats] retrogress.
The immovable [arhats] do not retrogress.
Furthermore, the dull-witted retrogress.
The sharp-witted do not retrogress.
Furthermore, those who eliminate [bonds] through the power of internal causes do not retrogress.
Those who eliminate [bonds] through the power of external conditions retrogress.
Some say:
Those who eliminate [bonds] through the preparatory practice of the contemplation of impurity retrogress.
Those who eliminate [bonds] through the preparatory practice of mindfulness of breathing do not retrogress.
Some say:
Those who eliminate the bonds to be eliminated through cultivation in the lower eight stages through the worldly path retrogress.
Those who eliminate [bonds] through the supramundane path do not retrogress.
It is like a terrace or pavilion with a shaky foundation that can be toppled.
If it is firm, it will not be so.
Question: Why do the upper three fruits have retrogression, but not the stream-enterer fruit?
Answer: The bonds to be eliminated by cultivation arise based on substantial things.
That is to say, there are pure aspects and impure aspects.
When one contemplates the pure aspects through improper attention,
one then retrogresses from the conception of impurity.
The bonds to be eliminated by the path of seeing,
arise based on insubstantial things.
There is not a single dharma that is the self or what belongs to the self,
that can cause one to retrogress from the view of non-self.
Question: Why did he compose this treatise?
Answer: In order to stop the MahÄsÄá¹ƒghika school's claim that the stream-enterer fruit has retrogression.
In order to show that the stream-enterer fruit is definitely without retrogression, he composed this treatise.
As for the bonds to be eliminated by cultivation arise based on substantial things,
it means that the grasped hair, body hair, nails, etc. are not completely without a small amount of pure aspect in the world.
If one contemplates this at an improper time through improper attention, one then retrogresses from the cultivated conception of impurity.
The bonds to be eliminated by cultivation that were previously eliminated arise.
As for the bonds to be eliminated by the path of seeing arise based on insubstantial things,ğŸ”½...
It means that the characteristics of self and what belongs to self that are grasped and attached to are ultimately non-existent.
Therefore the sutra says:
Dharmas have no function, nor do they have sentient beings, life, or nourishment.
The pudgala is neither the doer nor the experiencer.
It is only the accumulation of various activities, within which there is no self.
It is like using an empty fist to deceive young children.
The wise understand it as seeing an extended finger.
Therefore, having seen no-self, there is definitely no regression.
Therefore there is no regression from the fruit of stream-entry.
When regressing from the upper three fruits,
all the undefiled roots, powers, factors of enlightenment, and factors of the path that one has attained,
and so on at length.
Question: Why is this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to refute Venerable Saá¹ƒmati's statement that when regressing from the fruit of arhatship,
one only attains the previously abandoned factors of training in the future, and does not attain the past.
Why is this?
Because they are ultimately not manifested.
Now, in order to show that when regressing from the fruit of arhatship,
One obtains the previously abandoned wholesome dharmas of the past and future.
Although the past cannot be manifested, it can be accomplished.
For this reason, this treatise is composed.
When one falls away from the three higher fruits, the uncontaminated faculties, powers, factors of enlightenment, and factors of the path that one obtains,
should it be said that one obtains what was previously obtained or what was not previously obtained?
The answer is: it should be said that one obtains what was previously obtained.
This is because when one previously obtained the fruit, it was abandoned.
Now, when one falls away, one regains it.
All the previously unobtained noble paths are only obtained at the time of progress.
When one dies in the formless realm and is born in the desire realm, the aggregates, realms, and bases that one obtains,
and so on, are explained in detail.
Question: Why is this treatise composed?
Answer: It is also in order to refute the statement of Samghabhadra that when one dies in the formless realm and is born in the desire realm,
one only obtains the future dharmas that were previously abandoned, and not the past.
Why is this?
Because they are ultimately not manifested.
Now, in order to show that when one dies in the formless realm and is born in the desire realm,
This treatise is composed because one obtains the dharmas of the past and future that were previously abandoned.
If it were not so, when one dies in the formless realm and is reborn in the desire realm for the first time,
one should only accomplish the life-death of two time periods.
However, there are no sentient beings who only accomplish the life-death of two time periods.
Because one definitely accomplishes the contaminated dharmas of the three time periods.
When one dies in the formless realm and is reborn in the desire realm,
the aggregates, realms, and sense bases that one obtains, whether wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate,
the roots, bonds, latent afflictions, secondary afflictions, and entanglements,
should it be said that one obtains what was previously obtained or that one obtains what was not previously obtained?
The answer is: wholesome and defiled dharmas are obtained through what was previously obtained.
Ripened dharmas are obtained through what was not previously obtained.
As for wholesome and defiled dharmas being obtained through what was previously obtained,
wholesome refers to the four aggregates obtained through birth.
Some say:
One also obtains the four aggregates accomplished through hearing and contemplation.
These wholesome dharmas are previously abandoned due to transcending the realms and stages.
Now, since one returns to the realms and stages, one obtains them. As for defiled [dharmas],
That is, the four aggregates of non-good and obscured-neutral dharmas. These defiled dharmas
are first abandoned due to separation from defilements.
Now, they are obtained again due to coming to the realm and stage.
Question: Those who are well-versed in the four aggregates of deportment and craftsmanship should also obtain them.
Why is it not mentioned?
Answer: Although it should be mentioned, it is not mentioned.
One should know that this meaning is incomplete.
Some say:
For the most part, one does not obtain the undefiled-neutral dharmas.
That is, the whole of the dharmas born of retribution and the results of the spiritual faculties, and a small part of the rest.
Therefore, although one obtains a small part, it is also not mentioned.
Other masters say:
Those who are well-versed also do not obtain them.
Because they are weak.
As for the dharmas of retribution that are obtained but not previously obtained,
that is, those that have never been obtained since beginningless time, one only presently accomplishes them.
Question: The nourished aggregates are also obtained but not previously obtained. Why is it not mentioned?
Answer: Although it should be mentioned, it is not mentioned.
One should know that this meaning is incomplete.
Moreover, if you say there is a maturation, you should know that there is also nourishment.
Because nourishment protects the maturation.
It is like one person supporting another.
It is like a wall supporting another wall.
Because they must accompany each other.
At that time, there is also the attainment of the acquired nature of dharmas.
Because it is small, it is not mentioned, like the nature of ordinary beings and so forth.
When one dies in the formless realm and is reborn in the form realm, the aggregates, realms, and sense bases that one obtains
are wholesome and indeterminate.
The faculties, bonds, latent afflictions, secondary afflictions, and entanglements
should be said to be attained through prior attainment or attained through non-attainment?
The answer is: wholesome and defiled dharmas are attained through prior attainment.
Maturation dharmas are attained through non-attainment.
As for wholesome and defiled dharmas being attained through prior attainment,
wholesome refers to the four aggregates of innate wholesomeness
and the five aggregates of preparatory wholesomeness.
These wholesome dharmas are first abandoned through transcending the realms and stages.
Now, since one returns to the realms and stages, one attains them again.
Defiled refers to the four aggregates of obscured indeterminate.
These defiled dharmas are first abandoned due to separation from defilements.
Now, since one returns to the realm and stage, one obtains them again.
Among the undefiled-neutral dharmas, the four aggregates of the fruit of karmic maturation are also obtained through prior acquisition.
Because they are few, they are not mentioned.
The nourished and the homogeneous are explained as before.
When one dies in the form realm and is reborn in the desire realm, the aggregates, realms, and bases that one obtains,
are like those explained when dying in the formless realm and being reborn in the desire realm.
Here, the explanation should be understood as before.
When one, relying on the first meditation, arouses the supernormal power of spiritual penetrations,
how far can one reach at the farthest?
The answer is: up to the Brahma world.
When one, relying on the first meditation, arouses the supernormal power of divine hearing,
what kind of sound belonging to what realm can one hear at the farthest?
The answer is: up to the Brahma world.
When one, relying on the first meditation, arouses the supernormal power of knowing others' minds,
what kind of mind and mental factors belonging to what realm can one know at the farthest?
The answer is: up to the Brahma world.
When one, relying on the first meditation, arouses the supernormal power of recollecting past lives,
What past events can they recollect from the most distant past?
Answer: Up to the Brahma world.
When they use the supernormal power of heavenly eye developed based on the first meditation,
what forms can they see from the most distant?
Answer: Up to the Brahma world.
Just as based on the first meditation, up to based on the fourth meditation,
each according to its own place, the extensive explanation is also like this.
Question: Why is this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to make the doubtful attain certainty.
As the sÅ«tras and vinaya say:
Those with spiritual powers can freely transform their bodies up to the Brahma world.
Some give rise to such doubts:
The spiritual powers and freedom only reach the Brahma world, not the higher stages.
In order to make this doubt attain certainty,
it is said that the spiritual powers produced based on the fourth meditation
can freely transform the body up to the heaven of vast fruit or the ultimate form realm. Therefore this treatise is composed.
Question: If that is so,
how can the sÅ«tras and vinaya be understood?
Answer: If there is bodily expression of one's own stage in a place,
the World-Honored One speaks of it.
Above the second meditation, there is no bodily expression of one's own stage.
Therefore, it is not spoken of.
Some say:
In that place, the Buddha speaks of the highest stage initially attained, not the first attained.
Some say:
The word Brahma world includes the four meditations, because they all have the pure samÄdhi that is embraced by the members.
Question: Up to the first meditation, there is verbal expression,
so relying on the first meditation, the divine ear hears that sound. Above the stages, since there is no verbal expression,
relying on the second meditation and so forth, what kind of sound does the divine ear hear?
Answer: Just as one born in the first meditation, relying on the first meditation, gives rise to the mind that produces verbal action,
in the same way, one born in the upper three meditations also relies on the first meditation, gives rise to the mind that produces verbal action,
and that is precisely what is heard by the divine ear of that stage.
Some say:
Although the upper stages have no verbal expression or sound,
but there are other sounds that are heard by them.
Therefore there is no error.
Question: If one is born in the desire realm and, based on the first dhyÄna, gives rise to the divine ear supernormal power,
can one hear the sound of the bodily expression of the gods in the upper three dhyÄnas?
Some say one cannot hear it,
because the place is far away.
Or because it is subtle.
Some say,
if one makes a supreme effort, one can also hear it,
because it is a dharma of the same stage.
Question: Based on which dhyÄna does one give rise to the supernormal power of spiritual penetrations and be able to reach which place?
Answer: One who gives rise to it based on the first dhyÄna can reach the Brahma world.
Up to one who gives rise to it based on the fourth dhyÄna can reach the Bá¹›hatphala or Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heavens. ÅšrÄvakas, without making a supreme effort, can reach the smallest chiliocosm.
With a supreme effort, they can reach the middle chiliocosm.
Pratyekabuddhas, without making a supreme effort, can reach the middle chiliocosm.
With a supreme effort, they can reach the greatest chiliocosm. Buddhas, without making a supreme effort, can reach the greatest chiliocosm.
With a supreme effort, they can reach boundless worlds.
The four supernormal powers are also like this.
The detailed explanation of the six supernormal powers is like in the Great Aggregates.
If one attains the fruit of arhatship by contemplating suffering as suffering,
what kind of suffering does one contemplate?
Answer: The suffering associated with the formless realm.
This is said in general according to the realm.
If according to the stage, it should be said that the suffering associated with the neither-perception-nor-non-perception stage is the knowledge of the class of suffering.
If one attains the fruit of arhatship by contemplating the origin as the origin, what kind of origin does one contemplate?
Answer: The origin associated with the formless realm.
This is also said in general according to the realm.
If according to the stage, it should be said that the origin associated with the neither-perception-nor-non-perception stage is the knowledge of the class of origin.
If one attains the fruit of arhatship by contemplating cessation as cessation,
what kind of cessation of conditioned states does one contemplate?
Answer: Either associated with the desire realm,
or associated with the form and formless realms.
The cessation of conditioned states is the knowledge of dharmas of cessation and the knowledge of the class of cessation.
If one attains the fruit of arhatship by contemplating the path as the path,
What type of conditioned factors does this contemplation sever, and what is the path?
The answer is: either belonging to the desire realm, or belonging to the form or formless realms.
The path that severs conditioned factors is the path knowledge and the subsequent knowledge.
These six knowledges each have four aspects as the uninterrupted path.
Severing the lowest of the low grade of defilements of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, together with the vajra-like samÄdhi.
This is able to realize the fruit of arhatship, the vajra-like samÄdhi.
It is explained in detail in the third chapter of the Saá¹ƒyukta-Ägama.
The defilements of the form and formless realms to be severed by cultivation all use the six knowledges as the uninterrupted path.
Namely, the four subsequent knowledges, the knowledge of the cessation of suffering, and the knowledge of the path. This refers to the uncontaminated path.
If it is the contaminated path, it is only the conventional knowledge.
Because it is not universal, it is not mentioned here.
When the uninterrupted path of the knowledge of the class of suffering is produced based on the first meditation,
there is only that which takes the suffering of its own stage as its object.

There are those that only take the suffering of the second dhyana as their object, up to those that only take the suffering of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception as their object, without combining two.
Up to taking eight as their object.
Because of the difference in coarseness and subtlety, and because of the separate elimination of the stages.

Because of the equality in subtlety,
and because they all oppose defilement.

When the uninterrupted path of the knowledge of the aspects of cessation of the dharma arises,

When the uninterrupted path of the knowledge of the aspects of the path of the dharma arises,
it all takes the path of the class of knowledge of the aspects of the six stages as its object.
Just as based on the first dhyana,
Up to the sphere of nothingness, it is the same.

Here, all [realms] do not take the suffering and accumulation of lower [realms] as their objects.
Because it is useless to give rise to [the knowledge] when one is already free from the defilements of lower [realms].
